Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor assigned a code sample to be finished before the next meeting in three days.
Situation2: They conduct an in-depth consultation with a patient taking multiple high-risk medications to prevent dangerous interactions.
Story: I stared at the blinking cursor on my laptop, the unfinished code sample taunting me. My mentor had been clear: “Have this ready before our next meeting.” Three days. I’d promised myself I’d make her proud, show her I could keep up. But the pharmacy was busy today, and Mrs. Lee, a regular, had just arrived for her medication review. She was on a complicated regimen—anticoagulants, insulin, a new antipsychotic. I knew how critical it was to catch any dangerous interactions, to explain every detail so she’d be safe. My white coat felt heavier than usual as I led her to the consultation room, my mind split between the lines of code I needed to write and the responsibility I owed her as her pharmacist. I could feel the pressure mounting—my mentor’s expectations, my duty to my patient, both demanding my full attention. As Mrs. Lee began describing her symptoms, I tried to focus, but the unfinished assignment nagged at me, guilt and anxiety twisting in my chest. I wondered how I could possibly do justice to both roles when they seemed to be pulling me in opposite directions.
